title: Scrum Fundamentals & Roles
description: Master the three Scrum roles and understand distributed authority in Agile teams.
objectives: Understand the 3 Scrum Roles: Product Owner, Scrum Master, and Development Team
Recognize Product Owner responsibilities: Owns Product Backlog, maximizes value, prioritizes work, accepts completed work
Identify Scrum Master responsibilities: Servant leader, facilitates events, removes impediments
Understand Development Team characteristics: Self-organizing, cross-functional, 3-9 members, collective responsibility
Recognize that PO and SM are ONE person each, not committees or part-time roles
Apply the key mindshift: Traditional PM (command-control) → Scrum Master (servant leadership)

screens.headline: Chaos at Savory & Co.: Role Confusion Blocks Progress

items.title: CHAOS
items.details: Overlapping authority arrows - Maya adds to Product Backlog without Morgan approval, Alex assigns tasks

items.title: CLARITY
items.details: Three distinct role circles with clear boundaries - PO owns WHAT, Dev Team owns HOW, SM owns FACILITATION

dialogue.text: In Scrum, authority is DISTRIBUTED across three roles. Product Owner owns WHAT, Development Team owns HOW, Scrum Master owns FACILITATION. No single PM—but clear accountability.

screens.learningHook: Maya adds items to Morgan's Product Backlog. Alex assigns tasks to Devon. Carlos says: 'Who's in charge here?' Role confusion is blocking progress.

screens.title: Resolve the Role Confusion
screens.instructions: 4 scenarios test your understanding of Scrum role authority. For each situation, identify WHO has authority and HOW Alex should respond.

scenarios.title: Product Backlog Ownership
description: Maya adds 5 technical debt items to Product Backlog without Morgan's approval
Morgan is upset: 'I own the Product Backlog! Only I can add/remove items!'
Alex must clarify: Who owns the Product Backlog?

options.text: Development Team owns Product Backlog (they know what work is needed)
Product Owner owns Product Backlog (sole authority to add/remove/prioritize)
Scrum Master owns Product Backlog (facilitates backlog management)
Shared ownership (PO and Dev Team collaborate on backlog)

feedback.correct: Correct! Product Owner OWNS Product Backlog. Development Team can SUGGEST items, but only Morgan decides if they go in and at what priority. This is the foundation of Scrum: PO owns WHAT.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Only Product Owner owns Product Backlog. Dev Team can suggest items, but only PO has sole authority to add/remove/prioritize. This prevents chaos and ensures clear product direction.

questions.question: How should Alex respond to Maya adding items without Morgan's approval?

options.text: Tell Morgan to accept Maya's additions (Dev Team knows technical needs)
Clarify Morgan's authority, facilitate discussion between Morgan and Maya about the technical debt items
Remove Maya's items from backlog without discussion (PO authority is absolute)
Create separate 'Dev Team Backlog' so Maya can add technical items

feedback.correct: Perfect! Alex clarifies authority boundaries (PO owns backlog) AND facilitates collaboration (Maya can suggest, Morgan decides). This balances authority with team input.
feedback.incorrect: Not optimal. Alex should clarify Morgan's authority (PO owns backlog) but also facilitate discussion so Maya can SUGGEST items to Morgan. Authority is clear, but team input is valued.

scenarios.title: Sprint Backlog & Task Assignment
description: Alex assigns Devon a task: 'Devon, you take the plating design for Thai taco.'
Devon asks: 'Can you assign tasks? I thought we're self-organizing.'
Team is confused: Who decides Sprint work?

questions.question: Who decides Sprint work and task assignments?

options.text: Scrum Master assigns tasks to maximize efficiency
Product Owner assigns tasks based on priorities
Development Team self-organizes (team members decide who does what)
Team votes on task assignments each day

feedback.correct: Exactly! Development Team self-organizes. Team members collectively decide who works on what. NO ONE assigns tasks—not SM, not PO. This is core Agile: team ownership and autonomy.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. In Scrum, NO ONE assigns tasks. Development Team SELF-ORGANIZES—team members decide who does what. SM and PO don't assign work. This is fundamental to Agile team autonomy.

questions.question: How should Alex respond to Devon's question?

options.text: Defend task assignment: 'As Scrum Master, I coordinate work allocation'
Apologize for overstepping, clarify team self-organization: 'You're right, Devon. Team decides who does what.'
Ask Morgan (PO) to assign tasks instead
Compromise: 'I'll suggest tasks, but team can reject them'

feedback.correct: Perfect! Alex acknowledges the mistake (command-control habit) and clarifies Scrum principle: team self-organizes. This is the mindshift from traditional PM to Scrum Master.
feedback.incorrect: Not optimal. Alex should apologize for overstepping and clarify that team self-organizes. Assigning tasks (even with compromise) violates Scrum's self-organization principle.

scenarios.title: Who Accepts Completed Work?
description: Devon demonstrates new taco plating feature
Alex says: 'Looks good, mark it Done'
Morgan interrupts: 'Wait, I need to review—doesn't meet my acceptance criteria'
Who has authority to accept work as Done?

options.text: Development Team marks work Done when they complete it
Scrum Master validates work meets Definition of Done
Product Owner accepts work (validates meets acceptance criteria)
Stakeholders (Carlos, customers) accept work

feedback.correct: Correct! Only Product Owner accepts work as Done. PO validates that increment meets acceptance criteria and is ready for potential release. This ensures quality and alignment with product vision.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Only Product Owner has authority to accept work as Done. Dev Team builds it, SM facilitates, but PO is the sole authority on whether work meets acceptance criteria and product standards.

questions.question: How should Alex respond when Morgan says work doesn't meet criteria?

options.text: Override Morgan: 'It looks good to me, we're marking it Done'
Support Morgan's authority, add Product Backlog item to address the gap
Ask team to vote on whether work is Done
Escalate to Carlos (GM) to decide

feedback.correct: Excellent! Alex supports Morgan's authority (PO accepts work) and facilitates solution (add backlog item to fix the gap). This respects roles while moving forward.
feedback.incorrect: Not optimal. Alex should support Morgan's authority—PO is sole acceptor of work. If work doesn't meet criteria, it's not Done. Don't override PO or vote on quality standards.

scenarios.title: Removing Team Impediments
description: Team is blocked: supplier delays, legal approvals pending, IT provisioning slow
Maya: 'We can't move forward until these are resolved'

questions.question: Whose job is it to remove impediments blocking the team?

options.text: Development Team removes their own impediments (self-organizing)
Product Owner removes impediments (has stakeholder relationships)
Scrum Master removes impediments (primary servant leadership responsibility)
General Manager (Carlos) removes impediments (has organizational authority)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Scrum Master's PRIMARY responsibility is removing impediments. SM is servant leader—clears obstacles so team can focus on building. This is core SM role.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. While Dev Team can resolve some blockers, Scrum Master's PRIMARY responsibility is removing impediments. SM uses organizational influence to unblock the team—this is servant leadership in action.

questions.question: How should Alex respond to the blockers?

options.text: Tell team to work around the blockers (focus on what you CAN do)
Take ownership: 'I'll follow up with supplier, escalate to legal, push IT. This is my job—removing your impediments.'
Ask Morgan (PO) to handle the blockers (she has stakeholder relationships)
Assign impediment removal tasks to Dev Team members

feedback.correct: Excellent! Alex takes ownership of impediment removal—this is the Scrum Master's core servant leadership responsibility. SM works to unblock the team so they can focus on building.
feedback.incorrect: Not optimal. Scrum Master should take ownership of impediment removal. This is SM's primary responsibility—servant leadership in action. Don't delegate to team or PO.

blocks.title: Three Scrum Roles with Distributed Authority

content.definition: Scrum distributes authority across three roles—no single PM. Each role has clear boundaries and accountabilities.

roles.name: Product Owner (PO)
responsibilities: Owns Product Backlog (sole authority to add/remove/prioritize items)
Accepts completed work (validates meets acceptance criteria)

roles.name: Scrum Master (SM)
roles.authority: Owns FACILITATION (removes impediments, coaches, servant leadership)
responsibilities: Facilitates Scrum events (Sprint Planning, Daily Standup, Review, Retrospective)

roles.name: Development Team
characteristics: Self-organizing (team decides who does what, no task assignment)
Cross-functional (all skills needed to deliver increment)
Collective responsibility (no individual accountability, team owns outcomes)

content.insight: Authority distributed = faster decisions, clear accountability. In traditional PM, one person controls everything (bottleneck). In Scrum, three roles balance authority (speed + quality).
content.pmbokRef: Essential Scrum pages 15, 21, 23, 29; Agile Practice Guide page 40-42; PMBOK 7th page 35

blocks.title: Authority Boundaries: WHO Can Do WHAT

boundaries.note: Dev Team can suggest, but only PO decides
Team members decide who does what
Team estimates together (not PO, not SM)
SM uses organizational influence to unblock

boundaries.activity: Decide HOW to accomplish work (technical decisions)

content.insight: Clear boundaries prevent role confusion. When everyone knows WHO decides WHAT, teams move faster with less conflict.

comparison.scrum: SM has NO authority over team (servant leadership)

comparison.traditional: Command-control (PM tells team what to do)

comparison.scrum: PO prioritizes WHAT, Dev Team decides HOW (distributed authority)

comparison.traditional: PM assigns tasks to team members

comparison.scrum: Team effectiveness and product value (team outcomes)

content.insight: Traditional PMs transitioning to Scrum Master must UNLEARN command-control habits. Biggest challenge: letting go of task assignment and trusting team self-organization.

principles: No team lead (no one directs others)
Collective responsibility (team owns outcomes, not individuals)
3-9 members (optimal size for communication and collaboration)
Cross-functional (all skills needed to deliver increment—no external dependencies)
T-shaped skills (deep expertise + broad collaboration ability)
content.rationale: Flat structure = faster decisions, greater ownership, less bureaucracy. Teams with hierarchies revert to command-control (defeats Agile purpose).
content.insight: Individual accountability creates blame culture. Collective responsibility creates ownership culture.

content.principle: Product Owner is ONE person, NOT a committee. Clear authority = fast decisions.
rationale: ONE person = clear authority, fast prioritization, consistent product vision
clarifications: ONE PO per product (can't have multiple POs for same product)
PO can manage multiple products IF capacity allows
PO can delegate tasks (research, documentation) but NOT decision authority
content.insight: When PO is a committee, Dev Team gets conflicting priorities and product vision becomes muddled. ONE PO prevents this chaos.

correct.text: Exactly! I own the Product Backlog. Maya can suggest items, but I decide what goes in and at what priority. This clarity prevents chaos.

incorrect.text: Product Owner owns Product Backlog—sole authority. Dev Team can suggest, but only PO decides. This is fundamental Scrum: PO owns WHAT.

correct.text: Thank you for clarifying, Alex. Team self-organizes—we decide who does what. No task assignment. This is the Agile difference.

incorrect.text: I made a mistake assigning tasks. In Scrum, NO ONE assigns tasks. Team self-organizes. This is the hardest mindshift from traditional PM.

correct.text: Only I can accept work as Done. I validate it meets acceptance criteria and product standards. This ensures quality and value.
Removing impediments is MY primary responsibility. I'll follow up with supplier, escalate to legal, push IT. Team focuses on building—I clear obstacles.

screens.title: New Challenge: Scrum of Scrums (Multi-Team Scaling)
screens.context: Menu Innovation Lab has grown. Team doubled to 12 members, split into 2 teams: Team A (Morgan PO, Alex SM) and Team B (Sam PO, Jordan SM). Apply Scrum role principles to multi-team scaling.

questions.question: Can a developer from Team A add items to Team B's Sprint Backlog?

options.text: Yes—developers share work across teams
No—each team owns their own Sprint Backlog
Only with Scrum Master approval

feedback.correct: Correct! Sprint Backlog = team-level ownership. Team A owns their Sprint Backlog, Team B owns theirs. No cross-team interference.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Each team OWNS their own Sprint Backlog. Sprint Backlog is team-specific—Team A can't add to Team B's backlog.

questions.question: A feature involves both teams. Which PO accepts the work?

options.text: Both POs accept together
Whichever PO is available
The PO who OWNS that feature

feedback.correct: Correct! Feature ownership determines which PO accepts. If Morgan owns the feature, she accepts—even if Team B contributed work.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Feature ownership determines PO acceptance. Multiple POs accepting creates committee chaos (unclear accountability).

questions.question: How do Scrum Masters coordinate impediment removal across teams?

options.text: One SM becomes 'Chief Scrum Master'
Through Scrum of Scrums meetings
Each SM works independently

feedback.correct: Correct! Scrum of Scrums = SM coordination meeting. Alex and Jordan meet to sync on cross-team impediments and dependencies.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Scrum of Scrums meetings enable SM coordination. Creating hierarchy ('Chief SM') violates Scrum principles.

questions.question: Should there be ONE 'master PO' over 2 POs?

options.text: Yes—needs central authority
No—1 PO per product (if same product → 1 PO for both teams)
Depends on team size

feedback.correct: Correct! No hierarchy over POs. If it's ONE product → ONE PO for both teams. If two products → Morgan owns Product 1, Sam owns Product 2.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. PO structure based on product, not team size. One product = one PO. Creating 'master PO' hierarchy violates Scrum.

screens.title: Key Takeaways: Scrum Roles & Distributed Authority
screens.summary: You've learned the three Scrum roles with distributed authority: Product Owner owns WHAT, Development Team owns HOW, Scrum Master owns FACILITATION.
takeaways: Product Owner owns Product Backlog (sole authority to add/remove/prioritize items)
Product Owner accepts completed work (only PO validates work is Done)
Development Team self-organizes (NO ONE assigns tasks—team decides who does what)
Scrum Master removes impediments (primary servant leadership responsibility)
Development Team: 3-9 members, cross-functional, no hierarchy, collective responsibility
Traditional PM → Scrum Master requires mindshift (command-control → servant leadership)
Authority distributed: PO owns WHAT, Dev Team owns HOW, SM owns FACILITATION
